contentrichtext.text: {{for|the type of demon in [[Dungeons & Dragons]]|Balor (Dungeons & Dragons)}} :''For the locality in [[Mangalore]]. see [[Bolar (Location)]].'' {{More footnotes|date= March 2011}} In [[Irish mythology]], '''Balor of the Evil Eye''' (sometimes spelled '''''Balar''''' or '''''Bolar''''') was a king of the [[Fomorians]], a race of giants. His father was [[Buarainech]] and his wife was [[Cethlenn]]. According to legend, he lived on [[Tory Island]]. Balor was notable for his eye in the middle of his forehead and one directly opposite at the back, which meant he couldn't be sneaked up on from behind. According to prophecy, Balor was to be killed by his grandson. To avoid his fate, he locked his daughter, [[Ethlinn]], in a tower made of [[crystal]] to keep her from becoming pregnant. However, [[Cian]], one of the [[Tuatha Dé Danann]], managed to enter the tower with the help of the [[Druidry|druid]]ess [[Birog]]. Ethlinn gave birth to triplets by him, but Balor threw them into the ocean. Birog saved one, Lugh, and gave him to [[Manannan mac Lir]], who became his foster father. He was called [[Lugh]] Lamhfada and became a member of the Tuatha Dé Danann. Lugh led the Tuatha in the second Battle of [[Magh Tuiredh]] against the Fomorians. [[Ogma]] disarmed Balor during this battle, but Balor killed [[Nuada]] with his eye. Lugh shot a [[Sling (weapon)|sling-stone]], which drove Balor's eye out the back of his head, where it continued to wreak its deadly power on the Fomorian army. In other versions, Lugh blinded Balor with a spear made by [[Goibniu]] or decapitated him and used his eye against the Fomorians. One legend tells that, when Balor was slain by Lugh, Balor's eye was still open when he fell face first into the ground. Thus his deadly eye beam burned a hole into the earth. Long after, the hole filled with water and became a lake which is now known as Loch na Súl, or "Lake of the Eye", which is to be found in County Sligo. The folklorist Alexander Hagerty Krappe (1894–1947) <ref>Journal of American Folklore, Vol. 61, No. 240 (Apr. - Jun., 1948), pp. 201-202</ref> discusses the Balor legend in his book ''Balor With the Evil Eye: Studies in Celtic and French Literature'' (1927). Krappe believes Balor comes from a very ancient myth, perhaps, he suggests, going back to fertility rites at the time of the introduction of agriculture, of a woman (the earth) shut away by an old man (the old year), impregnated by another man, whose child (the new year), then kills the old man. Other versions of this myth: [[Gilgamesh]], [[Osiris]], [[Balder]], [[Danaë]], Balor in Ireland, the "May Count" in Sweden, and "it has even penetrated to Uganda, where it is told of a local chief."<ref>J.A. MacCulloch, ''The Childhood of Fictio''n," London, 1905, p. 411</ref> Moreover, according to Krappe, Balor is related to [[Janus (mythology)|Janus]], [[Cronus|Kronos]], the Serbian monster "Vy,"<ref>W.R.S. Ralston, ''Russian Folk Tales'', London, 1873, [http://books.google.pt/books?id=Nc0-JNw8ujMC&pg=PA72&dq=Vy+intitle:Russian+intitle:Folk+intitle:Tales+inauthor:Ralston&hl=pt-PT&ei=IlXvTczhNdOzhAfg5b2uCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Vy%20intitle%3ARussian%20intitle%3AFolk%20intitle%3ATales%20inauthor%3ARalston&f=false p. 72], cited by Krappe, p 4</ref> the Welsh [[Ysbaddaden]] Pennkawr,<ref>[http://www.bartleby.com/32/303.html The Poetry of the Celtic Races], [[Ernest Renan]]. Translated by W. G. Hutchison, II</ref> and other versions of a two-headed god with an evil eye.
